Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions: Genomics, functional roles, and diversity of the symbiotic gut microbiotae of honey bees and bumble bees
Award.AbstractNarration:
Microbial gut symbionts are essential for the life of most animal species, but their diversity and functions in hosts and their responses to ecological disturbance are poorly understood. Apis mellifera, the honeybee, possesses a distinctive set of about eight symbiotic bacterial species; some of these also occur in other Apis species and in the related genus Bombus (bumblebees). This study integrates the genomic, taxonomic and functional dimensions of the biodiversity of gut symbionts in these bees. The research will determine genome sequences and metabolic capabilities for these bacterial species and probe how their abundances and gene expression respond when hosts are subjected to different environments. The consequences of altered microbiota for host fitness will be experimentally assessed under nutrient stress and pathogen challenge. The study will also characterize the taxonomic composition of the microbiota of Bombus and Apis species collected globally, with emphasis on North America and China.

These pollinator species have immense economic, ecological, and agricultural importance; this project will provide new insights into their ecological resilience as mediated by their gut microbes. The data will inform bee conservation and land management policies. This effort will also establish a collaborative exchange with Chinese scientists. Several US students, at different levels, will be trained. High school student researchers and educational activities will be sponsored through the Peabody Museum in New Haven, CT. A large global collection of cryopreserved bees will be established to serve as a reference resource for future changes in bee populations. Overall, this research will provide novel insights into the biology of these important pollinators and their symbiotic microbial biodiversity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project encompassed investigations of the gut microbial communities living in honey bees and bumble bees, which are social insects and the most important agricultural pollinators. Senior investigators were Dr. Nancy Moran (Yale University and University of Texas at Austin), Dr. Jay Evans (USDA Bee Research Center, Beltsville, and University of Maryland), and Dr. Rachel WInfree (Rutgers University).

Investigators found that a consistent community containing the same specialized bacterial species lives in hindguts of honey bees and bumble bees. In honey bees, these include 8 species that comprise over 95% of the bacteria in the gut of each worker bee. The total community size is large relative to that found in most insect species, at about 1 billion bacteria per bee. These specialized bacterial species were cultured in the laboratory for the first time, and their genomes were sequenced and deposited in public databases. Formal species names were given to the bacterial species in the bee gut community, including Snodgrassella alvi, Gilliamella apicola, Bartonella apis, and Frischella perrara, and pure cultures of each were deposited in bacterial strain collections for use by researchers worldwide. Genomic and experimental analyses showed that these bacterial species play a role in digestion of food, consisting of nectar and pollen.  For example, Gilliamella apicola in honey bees has a very large number of genes for digesting and utilizing carbohydrates present in pollen cell walls and in nectar. The modes of transmission of the bacteria within the honey bee hive were determined using laboratory experiments on live bees. Methods for experimental inoculation of bees with known strains of the bacteria were established and used to determine how the bacteria affect the development and health of the bees.  The specificity of the bacterial strains to particular host species was studied, using experimental transfers of bacteria between honey bees and bumble bees. Experiments in which microbial gut communities were perturbed revealed that changes in early microbiota development can affect immune gene expression of the bees and influences susceptibility to pathogens. Finally, the evolutionary history of the gut bacterial communities in this group of bees was analyzed using samples from many bumble bee species and honey bee species, which are distributed in eastern Asia. These results showed that these bacteria are ancient associates that likely colonized the ancestors of honey bees, bumble bees and stingless bees over 80 million years ago, and that diversified with their hosts and became specialized on them.

Results were presented in 35 peer-reviewed scientific publications, and several more publications are expected from the results. 

This project provided extensive science education opportunities for students and the public. A total of 16 undergraduate students, from University of New Haven, Yale University, University of Texas and University of Maryland were involved in the research. In addition, 6 graduate students and 8 postdoctoral researchers worked on the project, with most receiving direct support from the award. Of the 8 postdoctoral researchers, 4 are now assistant professors and are continuing to conduct research on pollinator health, one is a Research Educator teaching research methods in related subjects to undergraduates, one is working as a Senior Research Scientist on pollinator health, and two continue as postdoctoral researchers on roles of bacterial communities in host biology. Several other graduate students had short internships based on the project. The project also involved several international scientists, including scientist from institutions in China, and one from an institute in Turkey.

 

The award was the basis for a new class within the framework of the UT Freshman Research Initiative in which students perform hands-on research starting as freshmen. The award was also used for classroom projects at Common Ground High School, in New Haven. Research supported by the award was incorporated into numerous science education and outreach efforts for the general public and for amateur beekeepers, including articles in newspapers and magazines.  The research was featured during several Family Day and Explore UT events at the University of Texas at Austin.
